I've recently been trying to do some simple exercises outside my knowledge scope in Lean, such as some basic calculus concepts. Specifically, I'm currently trying to prove that the product of the reciprocals of all prime numbers is 0. Mathematically, this is straightforward‚Äîit just requires a simple scaling argument. Arrange the sequence of primes in a line, and since the product of the reciprocals of all primes is less than 1/p, let p ‚Üí +‚àû.

But how can I implement this idea in Lean 4? Here is my example code:

/--
The product of the reciprocals of the primes is zero.
-/
open BigOperators Filter Topology Real Finset in
example : ‚àè' p : Nat.Primes, (1 : ‚Ñù) / p = 0 := by
  have h‚ÇÅ (p : Nat.Primes) :
    ‚àè' p : Nat.Primes, (1 : ‚Ñù) / p ‚â§ 1 / p := by

    sorry
  have h‚ÇÇ :
    Tendsto (fun (p : ‚Ñï) => (if Nat.Prime p then (1 : ‚Ñù) / p else 0)) atTop (ùìù 0) := by
    rw [NormedAddCommGroup.tendsto_atTop]; intro e he
    refine ‚ü®Nat.floor (1/e) + 1, fun n hn => ?_‚ü©; rify at hn
    by_cases htemp: Nat.Prime n <;> try simp_all
    exact inv_lt_of_inv_lt‚ÇÄ he <| lt_of_lt_of_le (Nat.lt_floor_add_one e‚Åª¬π) hn
  have h‚ÇÉ :
    Tendsto (fun (n : ‚Ñï) => ‚àè p ‚àà (range (n + 1)).filter Nat.Prime, (1 : ‚Ñù) / p) atTop
    (ùìù (‚àè' p : Nat.Primes, (1 : ‚Ñù) / p)) := by
    sorry
  have h‚ÇÑ :
    Tendsto (fun (n : ‚Ñï) => ‚àè p ‚àà (range (n + 1)).filter Nat.Prime, (1 : ‚Ñù) / p) atTop
    (ùìù 0) := by
    sorry
  exact tendsto_nhds_unique h‚ÇÉ h‚ÇÑ
You also have to prove that no matter what order you take the product in, it still tends to zero, at least in the way you've stated it here.

The definition of infinite sums and products in Lean is not the one typically given to undergraduates. For example 1‚àí(1/2)+(1/3)‚àí(1/4)+‚ãØ1-(1/2)+(1/3)-(1/4)+\cdots1‚àí(1/2)+(1/3)‚àí(1/4)+‚ãØ doesn't converge in Lean if you write it in the naive way as ‚àë' n : ‚Ñï, (-1 : ‚Ñù) ^ n / (n + 1).

The point is that in Lean the sum is not defined as "the limit, if it exists, of the finite sums from 0 to n", it's defined as "the limit, if it exists, of the sums over S where S is an arbitrary finite subset of the naturals", so there is an implicit assumption of absolute convergence which is not there in the traditional undergraduate exposition.

I just took a look at the docs, and what you have to prove exactly is that "Forall neighborhoods of zero, there exists a finite set, such that forall finite supersets of this set, the product of reciprocal primes within this superset lies in that neighborhood of zero."

And you can still give an argument similar to the informal one even with this absolute convergence business: given any œµ>0\epsilon>0œµ>0, take some ppp such that 1/p<œµ1/p<\epsilon1/p<œµ, and then take the finite set to be {p}\{p\}{p}; for any finite superset of this set, the product of all those inverse primes will still be less than 1/p1/p1/p and thus smaller than œµ\epsilonœµ.

I finally solved the simple example, yet in a somewhat funny way, since it deviated significantly from my original mathematical thinking. Here's the code:

open Filter Finset in
example : ‚àè' p : Nat.Primes, (1 : ‚Ñù) / p = 0 := by
  apply HasProd.tprod_eq; simp_rw [HasProd, one_div, prod_inv_distrib]
  apply Filter.Tendsto.inv_tendsto_atTop <| tendsto_atTop_atTop.2 fun M => ?_
  obtain ‚ü®S, hS‚ü© : ‚àÉ (S : Finset Nat.Primes), M ‚â§ ‚àè p ‚àà S, (p : ‚Ñù) := by
    obtain ‚ü®p, ‚ü®hp‚ÇÅ, hp‚ÇÇ‚ü©‚ü© := Nat.exists_infinite_primes (Nat.floor M + 1)
    use {‚ü®p, hp‚ÇÇ‚ü©}; rw [prod_singleton]; rify at hp‚ÇÅ
    exact le_trans ((Nat.lt_floor_add_one M).le) hp‚ÇÅ
  refine ‚ü®S, fun S' hS' => (hS).trans ?_‚ü©; norm_cast
  exact Finset.prod_le_prod_of_subset_of_one_le' hS' (fun x _ _ => x.2.one_le)

The lack of mathlib tactics and notation is less of an impediment than I expected it to be.
